children.value: This notebook demonstrates how to explore and analyze the Palmer Penguins dataset using
. You‚Äôll learn how to clean data, visualize relationships, and prepare for modeling.

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
url = "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/allisonhorst/palmerpenguins/master/inst/extdata/penguins.csv"
penguins = pd.read_csv(url)
penguins.head()

species     island  bill_length_mm  bill_depth_mm  flipper_length_mm  \
0  Adelie  Torgersen            39.1           18.7              181.0   
1  Adelie  Torgersen            39.5           17.4              186.0   
2  Adelie  Torgersen            40.3           18.0              195.0   
3  Adelie  Torgersen             NaN            NaN                NaN   
4  Adelie  Torgersen            36.7           19.3              193.0   

   body_mass_g     sex  year

children.value:
# Drop rows with missing values
penguins_clean = penguins.dropna()
penguins_clean.shape
Let‚Äôs visualize the distribution of penguin species and relationships between features.

# Bar chart of species count
penguins_clean['species'].value_counts().plot(kind='bar', title='Species Count')
plt.xlabel('Species')
plt.ylabel('Count')
plt.show()

# Scatter plot: Bill Length vs Bill Depth
for species in penguins_clean['species'].unique():
    subset = penguins_clean[penguins_clean['species'] == species]
    plt.scatter(subset['bill_length_mm'], subset['bill_depth_mm'], label=species)

plt.xlabel('Bill Length (mm)')
plt.ylabel('Bill Depth (mm)')
plt.title('Bill Length vs Bill Depth by Species')
plt.legend()
plt.show()
